An historic church left devastated in a fire had undergone £250,000 worth of restoration work, shocked parishioners said. 
The Church of Ascension in Lower Broughton, Salford , raised funds and secured grants with English Heritage and the National Lottery over three years for major work to be carried out. 
The church, built in 1869 and Grade II-listed, benefited from interior and exterior renovations, new roofing and pointing. 
Its website reveals the projects, which also included the creation of a community cafe inside, transformed the once ‘dilapidated’ church into a ‘fully accessible place of worship’. (Photo: Joel Goodman) Firefighters remain at scene after huge blaze at church overnight 
The blaze, which is under investigation, tore through the main body of the church late on Sunday night, February 12, and into the early hours of Monday. 
The fire service said the venue was left ‘completely devastated’ with the roof and interior ‘entirely gutted’. The cause of the fire is not yet known. 
Shocked parishioners gathered at the Church of England building on Ascension Road today to survey the damage. Many were reduced to tears as they spoke of the recent restoration work and fundraising. The Bishop of Manchester meanwhile urged the public to pray for the congregation. The Rt Rev David Walker called the fire ‘devastating’.
